titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ohio River Basin Environmental Council Records, 1948-2013 AIS.2017.02
titlestmt.author: David R. Lewis.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:07:39 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ohio River Basin Environmental Council Records
did.abstract: Documentation of the actions, research, and communications of the Ohio River Basin Environmental Council (ORBEC), which brought public attention to air and water quality problems caused by the industrialization of Neville Island in Allegheny County. ORBEC was particularly active in stopping approval of the Kosmos Cement Company's plans to burn of hazardous waste in their cement kiln on Neville Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Records documenting the founding, research, activism, and operation of the Ohio River Basin Environmental Council (ORBEC), which existed primarily to oppose the burning of hazardous waste in a cement kiln operated by the Kosmos Cement Company on Neville Island in Allegheny County. The collection is particularly rich in records documenting ORBEC's actions, including publications, research materials, correspondence, and meeting minutes, as well as the work of other community groups around the United States also opposing hazardous waste burning in cement kilns in the early 1990s. Additionally, there is substantial documentation of other environmental groups with which ORBEC was affiliated, including community-based organizations in Pennsylvania in the early 1990s, as well as national and governmental groups. There is also some documentation of the environmental community organizing around the industrialization of Neville Island that continued after ORBEC's most active period in the early 1990s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series:
Series IV. Community Groups Opposing Burning Hazardous Waste in Cement Kilns, 1990-1993

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Ohio River Basin Environmental Council (ORBEC), was formed in 1991 to bring awareness to the environmental consequences of industrialization on Neville Island, located in the Ohio River west of the City of Pittsburgh. Concerned citizens living on the northern shore of the Ohio River across from Neville Island, a heavily-industrialized area, organized the group and spent several years researching the effects of emissions from the Neville Island factories. They mobilized in the early 1990s to end the approval process that would allow Kosmos Cement to burn hazardous waste as fuel in the cement kiln on Neville Island, in cooperation with the Southdown Corporation which had recently expanded into hazardous waste processing. The burning of hazardous waste was ultimately not approved for the site and members of the group continued to work on other environmental causes. ORBEC remains active, though the bulk of the records in this are from the early 1990s, when the group was actively opposing burning of hazardous waste. The Kosmos Cement kiln on Neville Island was ultimately closed in April 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains bylaws and typed meeting minutes from ORBEC meetings in the early 1990s, as well as other administrative records, such as blank letterhead and administrative forms, calendars of ORBEC activities, and address lists. There are also several spiral-bound notebooks containing notes on meetings and other events from Janet Strahosky, an early member and record keeper of the group.

did.unittitle: Notebooks (meeting notes, to do lists, etc.)
Notebooks (meeting notes, to do lists, etc.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains published research, white papers, news clippings, and other public documents compiled by ORBEC on environmental issues, mainly related to the burning of hazardous waste in the cement industry. Also included is a large file of news clippings from local and national sources on subjects related to ORBEC's work, including pollutants, toxins, and environmental regulations.

did.unittitle: "Cement Kiln Incineration of Hazardous Waste, A Critique," Dr. Edward W. Kleppinger and Richard A. Carnes
"Safety of Cement Manufactured with Fuel Containing Hazardous Waste," Dr. James Cobb
List of kilns burning or proposing to burn hazardous waste

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains records from ORBEC's projects, largely relating to the Kosmos Cement Company's plan to burn hazardous waste in its cement kilns. Most folders contain research, correspondence, public records obtained by ORBEC, and publications about to Kosmos Cement sites, including industry publications. Research, correspondence, and white papers regarding local, state, and federal regulations are also represented. ORBEC's public comments, signed petitions and letters sent to government officials, and action alerts other documents meant for public use and consumption are also included here. ORBEC was instrumental in starting Environmental Advisory Councils (EACs), which are advisory boards connected to municipal governments, in several Pittsburgh-area locations, including Neville Township, Stowe Township, McKees Rocks, Ben Avon Heights, Bellevue and Avalon. Correspondence, ordinances creating the councils, collected research, and meeting minutes from the EACs are represented here, though records from the Avalon EAC predominate. Also notable are several folders of ORBEC's publications, including newsletters, reports, and press releases.

did.unittitle: Kosmos Cement kiln research: white papers and unpublished materials
Kosmos Cement kiln research: news clippings
Kosmos Cement research compiled by Ed Kleppinger
Ideas for op-eds and newsletter articles
News coverage of members and projects
Community Groups Opposing Burning Hazardous Waste in Cement Kilns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In the early 1990s, ORBEC was in contact with other community groups and individuals across the United States who opposed the burning of hazardous waste in cement kilns, many of which were operated by Southdown. This series contains correspondence, research, news clippings, letters, public records, and other documents shared with ORBEC by these groups and individuals.

did.unittitle: Ban The Burn, Fort Collins, CO
Citizens Aware and United for a Safe Environment, Midlothian, TX

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains information and records about environmental and governmental groups related to ORBEC, including newsletters, correspondence, publications and other documentation. It is divided into two sub-series; the first documents environmental groups based in Pennsylvania, with which ORBEC often had direct working relationships, and the second documents national and governmental groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains newsletters, correspondence, and publications from Pennsylvania-based environmental groups, many of which are community-based and with whom ORBEC worked closely. Of particular note is the folder on the Kosmos Cement Company Citizens Liaison Committee, which contained several ORBEC members. ORBEC also worked closely with the following organizations represented here: Clean Water Action, North Area Environmental Council, Pennsylvania Environmental Council, GASP, and Pennsylvania Environmental Network. The substantial records from the Chemical Community Advisory Panels are records of meetings between community members and chemical company representatives which, though they occurred after ORBEC was no longer an active organization, represent the continuing work of former ORBEC members.

did.unittitle: Center for Hazardous Materials Research, University of Pittsburgh
Kosmos Cement Company Citizens Liaison Committee
Southwestern Pennsylvania Alliance for a Clean Environment/Pittsburgh Against Toxic Incineration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains newsletters, correspondence, and publications from national or non-Pennsylvania-based environmental groups, as well as governmental entities that affected the work of ORBEC. Of particular note is the large amount of material from Greenpeace, the Clean Air Network and the Clean Steel Network, as well as the newsletters of the Environmental Research Foundation.

did.unittitle: Clean Steel Network, National Resources Defense Council
Environmental Research Foundation/Rachel's Hazardous Waste News
Local. State, and Federal Emergency Management Agencies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains handouts, agendas, schedules, transcripts and/or hand-written notes from several meetings and conferences on environmental topics. Of note are the undated typewritten transcript of the Allegheny County Local Emergency Managers meeting and the handwritten transcript of what is likely the state Air Pollution Control Board, both from the early 1990s. There are also materials from several conferences, including two years of the Beyond the Right To Know Conference, funded by the United States Public Interest Research Group Education Fund.

did.unittitle: Allegheny County Local Emergency Planning Committee meeting transcript
Air Pollution Control Board meeting transcript
Hazardous Waste Burning in Cement Kilns Press Conference, Allegheny County Commissioner Larry Dunn
Pennsylvania Environmental Network Leadership Development Conference
Pennsylvania Environmental Network Leadership Development Conference

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains correspondence with governmental bodies and representatives, as well as some of ORBEC's other outgoing correspondence. Of particular note is the large volume of correspondence with the Allegheny County Commissioners, Allegheny County Health Department, and West View Borough Water Department, as well as the personal correspondence between ORBEC member Janet Strahosky and State Representative David Mayernik.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series contains ORBEC's bank account statements, receipts, and financial statements.
